questions.text:
Which of the following statement is false regarding following below graph ?
1. "a" It is the minimum strength of stimulus that can elicit a biological response
2. Curve Q represent injured nerve
3. Curve Q represents reduced excitability of nerve
4. Curve 'p' represenst normal functioning of nerve
questions.solution:
• Statement 1 is correct: The point marked 'a' refers to rheobase, which is the minimum stimulus strength that can elicit a biological response such as nerve activation. It reflects the baseline level of excitability of the nerve.
  • Statement 2 is false: Curve Q represents a normal, functioning nerve, not an injured one. In a normal nerve, the excitability and response to stimuli remain intact, without signs of injury.
  • Statement 3 is false: Curve Q does not represent reduced excitability. Reduced excitability is observed in Curve P, which indicates an injured nerve. An injured nerve requires a higher stimulus to elicit a response due to its compromised function.
  • Statement 4 is false: Curve P represents the injured nerve with decreased excitability, requiring a stronger stimulus (higher threshold) to produce a response, which contrasts with the normal functioning shown in Curve Q.
  • Injured nerves often show higher thresholds and reduced responses due to impaired ion channel function, which reflects as reduced excitability on the graph.
  • The difference between the curves emphasizes the impact of nerve injury on electrical properties and the ability of the nerve to transmit signals effectively.

Why Not Other Options:

  • A (1 & 2 are false): Incorrect because Statement 1 is true, and 2 is false.
  • B (3 & 4 are false): Incorrect because both 3 and 4 are false.
  • D (1, 2 & 3 are false): Incorrect because Statement 1 is true; only 2 and 3 are false.

Key Takeaways:

  • Rheobase represents the minimum stimulus needed for a biological response.
  • Curve P indicates an injured nerve with reduced excitability, while Curve Q represents a normal nerve with typical excitability.

questions.text: Match the following
questions.solution:
• Neurapraxia (1) - c: Neurapraxia is a temporary block in nerve conduction, usually due to nerve compression or disrupted blood supply without structural damage to the axon.
  • Neurotmesis (2) - d: Neurotmesis is the most severe form of nerve injury, involving the complete destruction of the axon and surrounding encapsulated tissue. This requires surgical intervention for recovery.
  • Axonotmesis (3) - a: In axonotmesis, the axon itself is disrupted, but the surrounding connective tissue (nerve sheath) remains intact, allowing potential regeneration over time.
  • Denervation Hypersensitivity (4) - b: This occurs when there is post-synaptic upregulation of neurotransmitter receptors in response to loss of nerve input (denervation) leading to increased sensitivity.

Why Not Other Options:

  • B (1-d, 2-c, 3-a, 4-b): Incorrect because neurapraxia is not associated with destruction (d) but with compression (c).
  • C (1-a, 2-d, 3-c, 4-b): Incorrect as neurapraxia does not involve axonal disruption (a); this fits axonotmesis.
  • D (1-b, 2-a, 3-c, 4-c): Incorrect because neurapraxia involves compression, not hypersensitivity (b), and axonotmesis is related to axon disruption (a).

Key Takeaways:

  • Neurapraxia: Temporary, non-destructive nerve injury due to compression.
  • Neurotmesis: Complete nerve destruction requiring surgical repair.
  • Axonotmesis: Axonal disruption with potential for recovery.
  • Denervation Hypersensitivity: Upregulation of receptors after denervation leading to heightened response.

choices.text: Absolute refractive period corresponds to whole of depolarization and about one third of repolarization
Relative refractive period corresponds to period where the nerve can respond to a second stimulus provided it is greater than threshold strength
Action potential is conducted over short distance

questions.text: Which of the following is false statement?
questions.solution:
• Action potential is conducted over short distance: This statement is false because action potentials propagate along the entire length of the axon without diminishing, enabling long-distance communication between neurons. This is due to the regenerative nature of action potentials, which are constantly renewed as they travel.
    • Saltatory conduction in myelinated neurons allows faster transmission by jumping between the nodes of Ranvier.
    • In unmyelinated neurons, the action potential propagates continuously, but still over the entire membrane.

Why Not Other Options:

  • A. Absolute refractory period:
    • During this period, the neuron is completely unresponsive to any new stimulus because the sodium channels are either open or inactivated. This period includes all of depolarization and about one-third of repolarization, making the statement true.
  • B. Relative refractory period:
    • This is the period following the absolute refractory period when the neuron can respond to a stronger-than-normal stimulus. This period occurs during the latter two-thirds of repolarization, so the statement is true.
  • D. Local potential can be summed:
    • Local (graded) potentials are not all-or-none and can be summed. They can add up, either spatially (from multiple locations) or temporally (from rapid, successive inputs), to reach the threshold and initiate an action potential. This is a true statement.

Key Takeaways:

  • Action potentials travel across the entire axon and are regenerative, ensuring long-distance signal transmission.
  • The absolute refractory period prevents the generation of new action potentials during depolarization and early repolarization, while the relative refractory period requires stronger stimuli.
  • Local potentials can summate, leading to the generation of action potentials if they reach threshold levels.

questions.text: A research study is being conducted on the features of different nerve fibers. According to the study, the conduction velocity of Nerve fibers depends only on the diameter of the nerve fiber. Comparing the impulse velocity among the following nerve fibers, which of the following nerve fibers has the least conduction velocity?
questions.solution:
• C-fibers: These are unmyelinated fibers with the smallest diameter among all nerve fibers, resulting in the slowest conduction velocity. They are primarily responsible for transmitting sensations like slow, protopathic pain (second pain), warmth, and pressure. Due to their lack of myelination and small size, they conduct impulses more slowly compared to other fibers.
  • A-fibers (including A-Alpha and A-Beta) are large, myelinated fibers, meaning they have higher conduction velocities due to both myelination and large diameters.

Why Not Other Options:

  • A. A-Alpha fibers:
    • These are myelinated and have the largest diameter among nerve fibers, making them the fastest in conduction. They are involved in motor control and proprioception, which require rapid signaling.
  • B. A-Beta fibers:
    • These fibers are also myelinated and have a large diameter, though smaller than A-Alpha fibers. They conduct sensory information, such as touch and vibration, at high speed.
  • C. B-fibers:
    • B-fibers are myelinated but have a smaller diameter than A-Alpha and A-Beta fibers. They conduct signals at an intermediate velocity and are involved in autonomic functions.
  • Key Takeaways:
  • C-fibers are the slowest conducting nerve fibers due to their small diameter and lack of myelination, transmitting signals for gradual pain and temperature.
  • A-Alpha and A-Beta fibers are fast-conducting due to their large diameters and myelination, responsible for motor and sensory functions.
  • B-fibers fall between A-fibers and C-fibers in terms of conduction velocity, supporting autonomic activities.

questions.text: In 1943, Seddon described the basic types of peripheral nerve injury. These types assist in the assessment, prognosis, and determination of treatment strategy. Some of these injuries lead to irreversible damage, while others are reversible. Clinical history and physical examination are important in assessing the extent and severity of nerve Injury. Which of the following Seddon's peripheral injury types has the best prognosis?
questions.solution:
• Neuropraxia:
    • This is the mildest and most common type of peripheral nerve injury, caused by transient compression or stretch.
    • It involves focal demyelination at the injury site without disrupting the axon or connective tissues, leading to a temporary blockage of nerve conduction.
    • Motor and sensory loss is temporary, and autonomic function is generally preserved.
    • Recovery is typically spontaneous and occurs within 3 months as the nerve remyelinates, giving it the best prognosis of all types of nerve injury.
  • Axonotmesis:
    • More severe than neuropraxia, it involves complete axon disruption and demyelination, but the surrounding connective tissues remain intact.
    • This results in a complete loss of motor, sensory, and autonomic function.
    • Recovery is possible but depends on the distance from the injury, as regeneration of axons takes time.
  • Neurotmesis:
    • The most severe type, it involves a complete division of the peripheral nerve. The axon and connective tissue are both disrupted.
    • Recovery is not possible without surgical intervention, and the prognosis is poor.
  • Complete Transaction:
    • Refers to a full severing of the nerve, resulting in total loss of function with no possibility of spontaneous recovery.

Why Not Other Options:

  • A. Axonotmesis:
    • Although recovery is possible, it depends on the distance from the injury and takes longer than neuropraxia.
  • C. Neurotmesis:
    • Complete division of the nerve with no spontaneous recovery, making this option have a very poor prognosis.
  • D. Complete Transaction:
    • This implies total disruption of nerve continuity, making recovery impossible without intervention.

Key Takeaways:

  • Neuropraxia is the least severe and has the best prognosis, with spontaneous recovery occurring within months.
  • Axonotmesis and neurotmesis are progressively more severe, with axonotmesis showing some potential for recovery and neurotmesis having a poor outlook.
  • Complete transaction represents total nerve injury with no recovery possible without surgery

choices.text:
1- orthodromic, kinesin protein
2- antidromic, dynein protein

1- orthodromic, dynein protein
2- antidromic, kinesin protein

1- antidromic, kinesin protein
2- orthodromic, dynein protein

1- antidromic, dynein protein
2- orthodromic, kinesin protein

questions.text: Match correctly the type's of conduction shown in figure and the protein helpful in such conduction respectively.
questions.solution:
• Orthodromic conduction:
    • Refers to forward transmission of signals from the synaptic junction or receptor towards the axon terminal.
    • This is the natural direction of nerve impulse transmission.
    • Kinesin protein aids in anterograde transport, moving materials towards the axon terminal.
  • Antidromic conduction:
    • Refers to the reverse transmission of nerve impulses, from the axon terminal towards the soma.
    • This is an unnatural or backward conduction.
    • Dynein protein is involved in retrograde transport, moving materials towards the cell body.

Why Not Other Options (ABCD):

  • B. 1- Orthodromic, Dynein protein; 2- Antidromic, Kinesin protein:
    • Dynein does not support orthodromic conduction. It is involved in retrograde transport, making this incorrect.
  • C. 1- Antidromic, Kinesin protein; 2- Orthodromic, Dynein protein:
    • Kinesin supports anterograde transport, making it suitable for orthodromic conduction, not antidromic.
  • D. 1- Antidromic, Dynein protein; 2- Orthodromic, Kinesin protein:
    • The correct proteins are matched in reverse, making this incorrect.

Key Takeaways:

  • Kinesin protein facilitates anterograde (orthodromic) conduction.
  • Dynein protein is responsible for retrograde (antidromic) conduction.
  • The correct matching of conduction type and protein function ensures proper nerve signal transmission.
  • Remember: OK(orthodromic- kinesin) AD (Antidromic- Dynein)

questions.text:
Following number of statements are true regarding factors affecting the nerve conduction velocity.
1) Diameter of neuron is directly related to nerve conduction velocity.
2) Myelination - increases thickness of axon - and decreases velocity.
3) Myelination - decreases membrane capacitance and increases velocity
4) Myelination increases nerve transmission in myelinated nerve fibers by 5-50 folds
5) Diameter of neuron is inversely related to nerve conduction velocity.
questions.solution:
• Statement 1 (True): Larger diameter neurons have increased conduction velocity due to reduced internal resistance to ion flow.
  • Statement 2 (False): Myelination increases the thickness but does not decrease velocity; it enhances conduction velocity by insulating the axon.
  • Statement 3 (True): Myelination decreases membrane capacitance, which means less charge is needed to depolarize the membrane, leading to increased conduction velocity.
  • Statement 4 (True): Myelination increases conduction velocity in myelinated fibers by 5-50 times, primarily through saltatory conduction.
  • Statement 5 (False): Diameter is directly related to nerve conduction velocity, not inversely.

Why Not Other Options :

  • A. only 1: Ignores statements 3 and 4, which are also true.
  • C. 2, 4, 5: Statement 2 is false (myelination does not decrease velocity), and statement 5 is also false (diameter is directly related to velocity).
  • D. 3, 5: Statement 5 is false, as the diameter of the neuron is directly related to conduction velocity.

Key Takeaways:

  • Larger diameter neurons have faster conduction velocities.
  • Myelination enhances conduction velocity by decreasing capacitance and enabling saltatory conduction.
  • Myelination can increase nerve transmission speed by 5-50 times.

questions.text: In nerve physiology, there are two types of nerve fibers based on myelination. Myelination in peripheral nervous system & Myelination in central nervous system done by different types of supporting cells. Myelination in peripheral nervous system done by?
questions.solution:
• Schwann cells: Responsible for myelination in the peripheral nervous system (PNS), wrapping around axons to form the myelin sheath and enhancing signal transmission.
  • Oligodendrocytes: These are responsible for myelination in the central nervous system (CNS), providing myelin for multiple axons.
  • Astrocytes: Involved in the formation of the blood-brain barrier in the CNS, not myelination.
  • Ependymal cells: Line the ventricles of the brain and are involved in the production of cerebrospinal fluid (CSF).

Why Not Other Options :

  • A. Astrocytes: Function in the blood-brain barrier, not in myelination.
  • B. Oligodendrocytes: Myelinate axons in the CNS, not the PNS.
  • C. Ependymal cells: Involved in CSF production, not in myelination.
  • D. Schwann cells: Correct, they myelinate axons in the PNS.

Key Takeaways:

  • Schwann cells are responsible for myelination in the peripheral nervous system.
  • Oligodendrocytes myelinate axons in the CNS, while astrocytes and ependymal cells have other distinct roles.

questions.text: Antibodies against the voltage - gated calcium channels on the terminal button of the presynaptic motor neuron are seen in;
questions.solution:
• Lambert Eaton syndrome: In this autoimmune disorder, antibodies target voltage-gated calcium channels on the presynaptic motor neuron, preventing the release of acetylcholine and leading to muscle weakness. Proximal muscle weakness is more common especially lower limb muscles.
  • Myasthenia gravis: This condition involves antibodies against the acetylcholine receptors on the postsynaptic membrane, not calcium channels. Peripheral muscle weakness is primary feature mainly facial muscles to start with.
  • Guillain-Barre syndrome: A disease of the nervous system where the immune system attacks peripheral nerves, typically causing muscle weakness and paralysis, but it does not involve calcium channels.
  • Kartagener syndrome: A genetic disorder characterized by a triad of respiratory infections, infertility, and situs inversus due to defective axonemal dynein, not related to voltage-gated channels.

Why Not Other Options:

  • Myasthenia gravis: Involves antibodies against acetylcholine receptors, not calcium channels.
  • Guillain-Barre syndrome: Affects the nervous system, but not via antibodies against calcium channels.
  • Kartagener syndrome: Is a genetic disorder involving defective axonemal dynein, not related to nerve physiology.

Key Takeaways:

  • Lambert Eaton syndrome involves antibodies against presynaptic calcium channels.
  • Other conditions like Myasthenia gravis and Guillain-Barre syndrome target different structures or mechanisms in the nervous system.

questions.text: Nerve fibers classify by Susceptibility to Various Agents (Hypoxia, Pressure and Local Anesthetics), Group B nerve fibers are most susceptible to?
questions.solution:
• Classification of Nerve Fibers:
    • Type A: Thickly myelinated, large diameter, high conduction velocity.
    • Type B: Lightly myelinated, medium diameter, moderate conduction speed.
    • Type C: Unmyelinated, small diameter, slowest conduction velocity.
  • Susceptibility to Agents:
    • Hypoxia: Type B fibers are most susceptible to hypoxia due to their intermediate size and partial myelination.
    • Type C fibers are the least affected by hypoxia.
  • Pressure: Type A fibers are most susceptible because their large diameter and high conduction speed make them more prone to compression.
  • Local Anesthetics: Type C fibers are most affected because of their unmyelinated nature and small size, allowing easy blockade.

Why Not Other Options:

  • A. Pressure: Type A fibers are most susceptible, not Group B fibers.
  • C. Local anesthetics: Type C fibers are most affected due to small size and slow conduction.
  • D. Temperature: Temperature is not a significant factor in susceptibility classification.

Key Takeaways:

  • Group B fibers are most susceptible to hypoxia.
  • Type A fibers are affected by pressure, and Type C fibers are highly sensitive to local anesthetics.

questions.text: In the axoplasm, transport process can occur in both directions by different transport mechanisms. The maximal rate of axonal transport is.
questions.solution:
• Orthograde transport occurs along microtubules located along the length from cell body to axon terminals.
  • Types
    1. Fast axoplasmic transport: Occurs at a speed of 400 mm/day and is responsible for moving organelles and proteins quickly from the cell body to the axon terminals.
    2. Slow axoplasmic transport: Moves at a much slower rate of 5-2 mm/day and is important for transporting cytoskeletal elements.
  • Retrograde transport: Moves substances from axon terminals back to the cell body at a rate of about 200 mm/day.

Why Not Other Options:

  • 200 mm/day: This is the rate of retrograde transport, not the maximal rate of fast transport.
  • 600 mm/day and D. 800 mm/day: These values exceed the normal range for fast axoplasmic transport, which is limited to 400 mm/day.

Key Takeaways:

  • Maximal rate of fast axoplasmic transport is 400 mm/day.
  • Slow axoplasmic transport is much slower at 5-2 mm/day, and retrograde transport moves at 200 mm/day.

questions.text: During skeletal muscle contraction which of the following structures given in the figure are affected?
questions.solution:
Option C: During skeletal muscle contraction, the Z lines come closer so the length of I band and the length of H band decreases whereas there is no change in length of A band.

Option A: H band and A band: The A band remains the same length during contraction; only the I band shortens.

Option B: I band and A band: The A band does not change in length; only the I band shortens.

Option D: No change in I band: The I band does change, as it shortens during contraction.

Key takeaways:

During skeletal muscle contraction, the I band and H band shorten, the Z lines move closer, while the A band and M line remain unchanged.

questions.text: A 7-year-old boy presented with proximal muscle weakness and low IQ. Gower's sign is present. Which of the following protein (shown in the given figure) will be absent in this case scenario?
questions.solution:
Option B: The probable diagnosis is Duchenne muscular dystrophy(DMD). The dystrophin gene is one of the largest in the body and mutations can occur at many different sites in it. Duchenne muscular dystrophy is a serious form of dystrophy in which the dystrophin protein is absent from muscle. It is X-linked recessive disorder and usually fatal by the age of 30. Most common cause of death is respiratory failure. Patients with DMD will show malignant hyperthermia after anasthesia. Partial mutation of dystrophin gene leads to Beckers muscular dystrophy. Diagnostic test is Multiplex ligation probe dependent amplification(MLPDA).

Option A: Actin: Actin is a fundamental protein in muscle contraction and is present in all muscle cells.

Option C: Sarcoglycans: Sarcoglycans are part of the dystrophin-glycoprotein complex; they may be reduced but are not absent in Duchenne muscular dystrophy. Mutation in gene for sarcoglycan produces limb girdle muscle dystrophy.

Option D: Laminin: Laminin is a component of the extracellular matrix and is not absent in muscle diseases like Duchenne muscular dystrophy.

Key takeaways:

Absence of dystrophin is characteristic of Duchenne muscular dystrophy, which presents with proximal muscle weakness and Gower's sign.

questions.text: A 35-year-old female presented with difficulty in walking, fatigue and reduced reflexes. She was diagnosed to be the case of Lambert Eaton syndrome. Antibodies are produced against which channels?
questions.solution:
Option A: In Lambert Eaton syndrome, antibodies are produced against the voltage gated calcium channels present on the presynaptic membrane, which destroy the channels leading to muscular weakness.

Option B: Potassium channel.

Potassium channels are responsible for repolarizing the membrane after depolarization by allowing potassium ions (K+) to flow out of the cell.

Disease: Potassium channel autoimmune syndromes (e.g., Hypokalemic periodic paralysis).

Option C: Sodium channel:

Sodium channels play a crucial role in initiating action potentials by allowing sodium ions (Na+) to flow into cells during depolarization.

  • Disease: Na+ channelopathies (e.g., Sodium channel myotonia or periodic paralysis).

Option D: Chloride channel:

  • Disease: Cystic fibrosis Mucoviscidosis(due to mutations in the CFTR chloride channel located on chromosome 6). Most common mutation is ΔF508 deletion which codes for phenylalanine.

Key take aways:

In Lambert-Eaton syndrome, antibodies are produced against calcium channels leading to impaired release of acetylcholine at the neuromuscular junction and resulting in muscle weakness.

questions.text: A 48-year-old man was given dantrolene sodium as he was diagnosed with the case of malignant hyperthermia. There will be excessive release of which ions in this case?
questions.solution:
Option C: Prolonged opening of functionally altered ryanodine receptors leads to uncontrolled release of calcium from the sarcoplasmic reticulum resulting in sustained muscle contraction.

Option A: Potassium: Potassium is primarily involved in maintaining resting membrane potential and repolarizing the cell during action potentials. While potassium levels can increase during muscle contraction, it is not the primary issue in malignant hyperthermia.

Option B: Sodium: Sodium is involved in action potentials, but it does not play a central role in the mechanism of malignant hyperthermia.

Option D: Magnesium: Magnesium typically acts as a muscle relaxant and does not have a significant role in the pathophysiology of malignant hyperthermia.

Key takeaways:

In malignant hyperthermia, there is excessive release of calcium from the sarcoplasmic reticulum, leading to increased muscle contraction and heat production. Dantrolene sodium works by blocking this calcium release.

questions.text: A 58-year old male complained about fatigability on repeated activity, ptosis, and diplopia, difficulty in swallowing and difficulty in speech. Antibodies are produced against which of the following thing?
questions.solution:
Option C: In Myasthenia gravis, antibodies are produced against the nicotinic acetylcholine receptor, which can reduce its functional presence at the muscle membrane by up to 80%, and thus limit muscle response to neuronal transmitter release.

Option A: Calcium channels: Antibodies against calcium channels are associated with Lambert-Eaton syndrome, not myasthenia gravis.

Option B: Chloride channels: Chloride channels are not the target in myasthenia gravis; they are involved in other conditions like cystic fibrosis.

Option D: Potassium channels: Potassium channels are involved in various channelopathies but are not associated with the autoimmune response seen in myasthenia gravis. Disorders associated with potassium channel dysfunction include neuromyotonia or episodic ataxia.

Key takeaways:

questions.text: A 48-year-old man was diagnosed with congestive heart failure (CHF). Digoxin was given for treating his conditions. Which of the following statement is correct regarding the action of Digoxin?
questions.solution:
Digoxin selectively binds and inhibits the Na+/K+ATPase pump of myocardial fibers.

The block of the Na+/K+ATPase in cardiomyocytes would result in an increased intracellular Na+ concentration. Such an increase would result in a decreased Na+ influx and hence Ca2+ efflux via the Na+-Ca2+ exchange antiport during the Ca2+ recovery period. The resulting increase in intracellular Ca2+ concentration in turn increases the strength of contraction of the cardiac muscle.

A. Activates Na+/K+ ATPase pump: The Na+/K+-ATPase pump normally functions to pump sodium (Na+) out and potassium (K+) into the cell, maintaining the ion gradient essential for cell function. Digoxin inhibits this pump, rather than activating it.

B. Increases potassium influx: Digoxin leads to a decrease in the activity of the Na+/K+ ATPase, which can result in less potassium being moved into the cell.

C. Increases chloride influx: Digoxin primarily affects sodium and potassium, not chloride.

Key takeaways:

Action of digoxin is that it inhibits the Na+/K+ ATPase pump leading to increased intracellular sodium and calcium.

questions.text: A 26-year-old man committed suicide after suffering from depression who was staying alone in the house. Next day morning the neighbours suspected something wrong in the house. They called up the CID and open the door. CID officers tried to move the dead body but the body has become very stiff. What could be the reason behind the stiffness of the dead body?
questions.solution:
Several hours after death all the muscles of the body go into a state of contracture called rigor mortis.

When muscle fibers are completely depleted of ATP and phosphorylcreatine, they develop a state of rigidity called rigor. When this occurs after death, the condition is called rigor mortis. In rigor, almost all of the myosin heads attach to actin but in an abnormal, fixed, and resistant way. The muscles effectively are locked into place and become quite stiff to the touch.

A. Algor mortis: This refers to the cooling of the body after death, not stiffness. Once the heart stops beating, the body can no longer maintain its internal temperature, and it gradually cools to match the surrounding environment.

B. Liver mortis: Also known as hypostasis, this refers to the pooling of blood in the dependent parts of the body due to gravity, causing discoloration, not stiffness. Liver mortis is helpful in determining the position of the body at the time of death.

D. Cadaveric lividity: This is another term for liver mortis, indicating blood settling and causing discoloration, not stiffness.

Key takeaways:

The stiffness of the dead body is due to rigor mortis which is the postmortem stiffening of muscles caused by chemical changes in the muscle fibers after death.

choices.text: Instead of Z lines, there are dense bodies
Multi-unit smooth muscles are found in walls of hollow viscera

questions.text: Which of the following statement is not correct regarding the muscle shown in the figure?
questions.solution:
Option C: Smooth muscle can be divided into unitary (or visceral) smooth muscle and multiunit smooth muscle.

Unitary smooth muscle is found primarily in the walls of hollow viscera. The musculature of the intestine, the uterus, and the ureters are examples. Multiunit smooth muscle is made up of individual units with few (or no) gap junctional bridges. It is found in structures such as the iris of the eye in which fine, graded contractions occur. Blood vessels have both unitary and multi-unit smooth muscle in their walls.

Option A: Latch-bridge mechanism is seen: This mechanism is characteristic of smooth muscle, allowing for prolonged contractions with minimal energy expenditure.

Option B: Instead of Z lines, there are dense bodies: In smooth muscle dense bodies serve a similar function to Z lines in striated muscle, anchoring the actin filaments.

Option D: No elasticity is seen: This is incorrect because smooth muscle does exhibit elasticity, allowing it to return to its original shape after stretching.

Key takeaways:

Unitary smooth muscle (or visceral smooth muscle) is found in the walls of hollow viscera, while multi-unit smooth muscle is found in structures like the iris and blood vessels.

questions.text: A 3-year-old girl was brought to the emergency department with weakness in her left leg. On examination, her left leg appeared flaccid and no deep tendon reflex or Babinski reflex can be elicited. What is the probable diagnosis of this case in which the anterior horn cells (shown in the figure) are destroyed?
questions.solution:
The probable diagnosis is Poliomyelitis. Poliomyelitis is an inflammatory myopathy in which weakness of proximal limb muscles is an early feature. It is due to destruction of lower motor neurons present in the anterior horn of spinal cord by the poliovirus, resulting in paralysis of skeletal muscles.

Option A: Tetanus: Tetanus is caused by the neurotoxin produced by the bacterium Clostridium tetani. Tetanus causes muscle spasms and rigidity due to the toxin affecting the motor neurons, but it does not specifically destroy anterior horn cells.

Option C: Rabies: Rabies affects the central nervous system and can cause various neurological symptoms, but it does not specifically lead to flaccid paralysis from anterior horn cell destruction. The paralysis associated with rabies is not limited to a specific limb.

Option D: Botulism: Botulism leads to muscle weakness and paralysis due to the blockade of acetylcholine release at the neuromuscular junction, but it does not involve the destruction of anterior horn cells

Key takeaways:

Poliomyelitis specifically results in the destruction of anterior horn cells, causing flaccid paralysis.

questions.text: A 35-year-old male came to urology department with complaints of erectile dysfunction. He was prescribed Sildenafil for his conditions. What is wrong regarding Sildenafil?
questions.solution:
Option A: Sildenafil is a phosphodiesterase-5 inhibitor which increases cyclic CGMP (not cyclic AMP) and responsible for relaxation of smooth muscle of corpus cavernosum.

Option B: PDE-5 Inhibitor: Sildenafil specifically inhibits phosphodiesterase type 5 (PDE-5), which is true and a key mechanism of its action.

Option C: Relaxation of smooth muscles: By increasing cGMP levels, sildenafil promotes the relaxation of smooth muscles in the corpus cavernosum, facilitating increased blood flow and erection.

Option D: Produces penile erection: Sildenafil enhances erectile function by promoting blood flow to the penis, which results in an erection.

Key takeaways:

Sildenafil actually increases cyclic GMP (cGMP) levels by inhibiting phosphodiesterase type 5 (PDE-5), leading to relaxation of smooth muscles and facilitating penile erection, not cyclic AMP.

choices.text: Phase 2 is plateau phase due to calcium influx via the L type calcium channels
Phase 1 is Early repolarization phase due to potassium efflux
Phase 0 is Repolarization phase due to sodium efflux
Phase 3 is Late repolarization phase due to continued potassium efflux

questions.text: Which of the following statement is least correct regarding the ventricular action potential (shown in the given figure)?
questions.solution:
Option C: The initial rapid depolarization and the overshoot (phase 0) are due to opening of voltage-gated Na+ channels similar to that occurring in nerve and skeletal muscle. The initial rapid repolarization (phase 1) is due to closure of Na+ channels and opening of one type of K+ channel. The subsequent prolonged plateau (phase 2) is due to a slower but prolonged opening of voltage-gated Ca2+ channels. Final repolarization (phase 3) to the resting membrane potential (phase 4) is due to closure of the Ca2+ channels and a slow, delayed increase of K+ efflux through various types of K+ channels.

Option A: Phase 2 is plateau phase due to calcium influx via the L-type calcium channels: This is true; Phase 2 is characterized by a prolonged plateau caused by calcium influx, which helps maintain depolarization.

Option B: Phase 1 is Early repolarization phase due to potassium efflux: This is correct; Phase 1 involves a rapid repolarization due to the efflux of potassium ions (K+) as sodium channels close

Option D: Phase 3 is Late repolarization phase due to continued potassium efflux: This is accurate; Phase 3 is marked by continued potassium efflux, leading to repolarization of the membrane potential.

Key takeaways:

Phase 0 is the depolarization phase caused by the influx of sodium ions (Na+) through voltage-gated sodium channels, not repolarization or sodium efflux.

questions.text: A 38-year-old man was suffering from bronchial asthma for which he was given Salbutamol (Albuterol). What will be the effect of Salbutamol?
questions.solution:
Option A: Salbutamol is a short acing Beta-2 Agonist (SABA) used for the treatment of bronchial asthma. They act rapidly and frequently allow for sufficient opening of the conducting airway to restore airflow, and thus allow other treatments to reduce airway obstruction.

Salbutamol can also inhibit the release of inflammatory mediators from mast cells in the airways, contributing to its bronchodilatory effect. In addition, salbutamol can enhance mucociliary clearance, further aiding in the relief of symptoms.

Option B: Obstruction of airway: This is incorrect; Salbutamol is used to relieve airway obstruction, not cause it.

Option C: Antagonist of beta adrenergic receptors: This is false; Salbutamol is an agonist of beta-2 adrenergic receptors, not an antagonist.

Option D: Bronchoconstriction: This is incorrect; Salbutamol causes bronchodilation, not bronchoconstriction.

Option B, C and D worsens the symptoms of asthma rather than improvement of disease.

Key takeaways:

Salbutamol is a beta-2 adrenergic agonist that induces bronchodilation by relaxing bronchial smooth muscles, helping to alleviate bronchial obstruction in asthma.
